trans-unit.source: Remote Desktop enables you to access the desktop of a role running in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Remote Desktop enables you to access the desktop of a role running in Azure.

trans-unit.source: You can use a Remote Desktop connection to troubleshoot and diagnose problems with your application while it is running.

trans-unit.source: This article describes how to enable remote desktop on your Cloud Service Roles using PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: This article describes how to enable remote desktop on your Cloud Service Roles using PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: See [How to install and configure Azure PowerShell](powershell-install-configure.md) for the prerequisites needed for this article.
trans-unit.target: See [How to install and configure Azure PowerShell](powershell-install-configure.md) for the prerequisites needed for this article.

trans-unit.source: PowerShell uses the Remote Desktop Extension approach so you can enable Remote Desktop even after the application is deployed.
trans-unit.target: PowerShell uses the Remote Desktop Extension approach so you can enable Remote Desktop even after the application is deployed.

trans-unit.source: Configure Remote Desktop from PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Configure Remote Desktop from PowerShell

trans-unit.source: The [Set-AzureServiceRemoteDesktopExtension](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn495117.aspx) cmdlet allows you to enable Remote Desktop on specified roles or all roles of your cloud service deployment.
trans-unit.target: The [Set-AzureServiceRemoteDesktopExtension](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn495117.aspx) cmdlet allows you to enable Remote Desktop on specified roles or all roles of your cloud service deployment.

trans-unit.source: The cmdlet lets you specify the Username and Password for the remote desktop user through the *Credential* parameter which accepts a PSCredential object.
trans-unit.target: The cmdlet lets you specify the Username and Password for the remote desktop user through the *Credential* parameter which accepts a PSCredential object.

trans-unit.source: If you are using PowerShell interactively you can easily set the PSCredential object by calling the [Get-Credentials](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh849815.aspx) cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: If you are using PowerShell interactively you can easily set the PSCredential object by calling the [Get-Credentials](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh849815.aspx) cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: This will display a dialog box allowing you to enter the username and password for the remote user in a secure manner.
trans-unit.target: This will display a dialog box allowing you to enter the username and password for the remote user in a secure manner.

trans-unit.source: Since PowerShell will mostly be used for automation scenarios you can also setup the PSCredential object in a way that doesn't require user interaction.
trans-unit.target: Since PowerShell will mostly be used for automation scenarios you can also setup the PSCredential object in a way that doesn't require user interaction.

trans-unit.source: To do this first you need to setup a secure password.
trans-unit.target: To do this first you need to setup a secure password.

trans-unit.source: You begin with specifying a plain text password convert it to a secure string using [ConvertTo-SecureString](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh849818.aspx).
trans-unit.target: You begin with specifying a plain text password convert it to a secure string using [ConvertTo-SecureString](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh849818.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Next you need to convert this secure string into an encrypted standard string using [ConvertFrom-SecureString](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh849814.aspx).
trans-unit.target: Next you need to convert this secure string into an encrypted standard string using [ConvertFrom-SecureString](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh849814.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Now you can save this encrypted standard string to a file using [Set-Content](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/ee176959.aspx).
trans-unit.target: Now you can save this encrypted standard string to a file using [Set-Content](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/ee176959.aspx).

trans-unit.source: When creating the PSCredential object you can read from this file to set the password in a secure way without having to specify the password on a prompt or storing the password as plain text.
trans-unit.target: When creating the PSCredential object you can read from this file to set the password in a secure way without having to specify the password on a prompt or storing the password as plain text.

trans-unit.source: You get set it by specifying a static date and time or you could simply choose to expire the account a few days from the current date.

trans-unit.source: The [Get-AzureRemoteDesktopFile](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn495261.aspx) cmdlet can be used to remote desktop into a specific role instance of your cloud service.
trans-unit.target: The [Get-AzureRemoteDesktopFile](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn495261.aspx) cmdlet can be used to remote desktop into a specific role instance of your cloud service.

trans-unit.source: You can use the *LocalPath* parameter on the cmdlet to download the RDP file locally or you can use the *Launch* parameter to directly launch the Remote Desktop Connection dialog to access the cloud service role instance.
trans-unit.target: You can use the *LocalPath* parameter on the cmdlet to download the RDP file locally or you can use the *Launch* parameter to directly launch the Remote Desktop Connection dialog to access the cloud service role instance.

trans-unit.source: The [Get-AzureServiceRemoteDesktopExtension](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn495261.aspx) cmdlet displays whether remote desktop is enabled on a service deployment.
trans-unit.target: The [Get-AzureServiceRemoteDesktopExtension](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn495261.aspx) cmdlet displays whether remote desktop is enabled on a service deployment.

trans-unit.source: The cmdlet will return the username for the remote desktop user and the roles that the remote desktop extension is enabled on.
trans-unit.target: The cmdlet will return the username for the remote desktop user and the roles that the remote desktop extension is enabled on.

trans-unit.target: Remove Remote Desktop extension from a service

trans-unit.source: If you have already enabled the remote desktop extension on a deployment and need to update the remote desktop settings then you must first remove the remote desktop extension and then enable it again with the new settings.
trans-unit.target: If you have already enabled the remote desktop extension on a deployment and need to update the remote desktop settings then you must first remove the remote desktop extension and then enable it again with the new settings.

trans-unit.source: For example if you want to set a new password for the remote user account or if the user account has expired then you need to remove the extension and then add it again with the new password or expiration.
trans-unit.target: For example if you want to set a new password for the remote user account or if the user account has expired then you need to remove the extension and then add it again with the new password or expiration.

trans-unit.source: This is only required on existing deployments which have the remote desktop extension enabled.
trans-unit.target: This is only required on existing deployments which have the remote desktop extension enabled.

trans-unit.source: For new deployments you can call simply apply the extension directly.
trans-unit.target: For new deployments you can call simply apply the extension directly.

trans-unit.source: To remove the remote desktop extension from s service deployment you can use the [Remove-AzureServiceRemoteDesktopExtension](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn495280.aspx) cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To remove the remote desktop extension from s service deployment you can use the [Remove-AzureServiceRemoteDesktopExtension](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn495280.aspx) cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: You can also optionally specify the deployment slot and role from which you want to remove the remote desktop extension.
trans-unit.target: You can also optionally specify the deployment slot and role from which you want to remove the remote desktop extension.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The *UninstallConfiguration* parameter will uninstall any extension configuration that was applied to the service.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The *UninstallConfiguration* parameter will uninstall any extension configuration that was applied to the service.

trans-unit.source: All extension configuration is associated with the service configuration to activate the extension with a deployment the deployment must be associated with that extension configuration.
trans-unit.target: All extension configuration is associated with the service configuration to activate the extension with a deployment the deployment must be associated with that extension configuration.

trans-unit.source: Calling the Remove cmdlet without *UninstallConfiguration* will disassociate the deployment from the extension configuration thus effectively removing the extension from the deployment.
trans-unit.target: Calling the Remove cmdlet without *UninstallConfiguration* will disassociate the deployment from the extension configuration thus effectively removing the extension from the deployment.

trans-unit.source: However the extension configuration will still remain associated with the service.
trans-unit.target: However the extension configuration will still remain associated with the service.

trans-unit.source: To completely remove the extension configuration you should call the Remove cmdlet with the *UninstallConfiguration* parameter.
trans-unit.target: To completely remove the extension configuration you should call the Remove cmdlet with the *UninstallConfiguration* parameter.
